clonotypr

Source: vignettes/clonotypr.Rmd
clonotypr.Rmd

Setup

Currently, clonotypr can be downloaded directly from Github:

install.packages("devtools")

devtools::install_github("mattfemia/clonotypr")
library(clonotypr)

clonotypr offers the capability to build on top of objects in the Seurat library. Example seurat object, pbmc_vdj and pbmc_null are built-in to the package.
* pbmc_null –> Does not contain clonotype data
* pbmc_vdj –> Contains clonotype data in the meta.data slot

Data used to construct both pbmc_null and pbmc_vdj originates from human PBMCs and is provided by 10X Genomics. More information about the sample, the scRNA seq strategy, and the VDJ libraries can be found here

To learn more about the Seurat library, their developers offer many helpful vignettes here

Processing Data

AddClonotypes() and LoadClonotypes() are the quintessential functions for clonotypr:
* LoadClonotypes() – Creates a new dataframe, no Seurat object needed
* AddClonotypes() – Appends clonotype data to Seurat objects

While the latter function takes a Seurat object as input, future development will be more inclusive of other platforms.

Both require two files from the CellRanger outputs:

  1. filtered_contig_annotations.csv
  2. clonotypes.csv

To ease the transition into a single-file upload situation (Shiny), two arguments are available for passing the files into the function call:

  1. Upload a directory with the directory argument
  2. Individual file upload with clonotypeFile (clonotypes.csv) and filteredContigFile (filtered_contigs_annotations.csv)

Here, we’ll work with the Seurat object:

head(pbmc_null@meta.data)

object@meta.data before adding clonotype data:

orig.ident nCount_RNA nFeature_RNA
AAACCTGTCAACGGGA SeuratProject 5433 1470
AAACGGGGTTAAAGAC SeuratProject 3226 1147
AAAGATGAGTCACGCC SeuratProject 7432 1958
AAAGATGCAGCTGCAC SeuratProject 7105 2014
AAAGATGCAGTAGAGC SeuratProject 6313 1504
AAAGATGCATCCGTGG SeuratProject 3541 1364

Call AddClonotypes()

clonoFile <- system.file("extdata", "vdj_v1_hs_pbmc3_t_clonotypes.csv", package = "clonotypr")
fcaFile <- system.file("extdata", "vdj_v1_hs_pbmc3_t_filtered_contig_annotations.csv", package = "clonotypr")

clono <- AddClonotypes(pbmc_null, 
                      clonotypeFile = clonoFile, 
                      filteredContigFile = fcaFile) # Individual file upload
head(clono@meta.data)

Data appended to object@meta.data:

orig.ident nCount_RNA nFeature_RNA barcode clonotype_id v_gene d_gene j_gene c_gene cdr3s_aa cdr3s_nt

Clonotype Chains

DescribeClonotypes allows for quickly checking the distribution of clonotype chain types in your sample.

DescribeClonotypes(clono)
#> GetBarcodeFreqs will be deprecated in clonotypr 1.0.0. Use the updated params in MakeFrequencyDF for same functionality
#> MakeBarcodeDF will be deprecated in clonotypr 1.0.0
#> $`Productive Clonotypes`
#> [1] 672
#> 
#> $`Single-Chain Clonotypes(Alpha)`
#> [1] 10
#> 
#> $`Single-Chain Clonotypes(Beta)`
#> [1] 107
#> 
#> $`Multi-Chain Clonotypes`
#> [1] 142

Frequency Analysis

Raw Frequency

Similar to the data in the filtered_contig_annotations.csv file, clonotypr calculates the raw frequency and percentage of each individual clonotype relative to the total sample population.

freqs <- MakeFrequencyDF(clono)
freqs[freqs$clonotypeVector[35:45],]
nrow(freqs)
clonotype_id freq percent cdr3s_aa cdr3s_nt 
#> [1] 937

Single-Chain Clonotypes

However, clonotypr also handles the likelihood of encountering clonotypes which contain only an alpha or beta chain. In situations where clonotype frequency requires high precision within a sample, use JoinSingleChains to resolve this. Here, the individual CDR3alpha and CDR3beta chains are first isolated. Then the frequency of those single-chain clonotypes are added into the frequency of productive clonotypes. Then only the productive clonotypes and frequencies are returned.

prod_freqs <- JoinSingleChains(clono)
prod_freqs[prod_freqs$clonotypeVector[35:45],]
nrow(prod_freqs)
clonotype_id freq percent cdr3s_aa cdr3s_nt 
#> [1] 820

CDR3 Lengths

CDR3 chain length can be analyzed in two ways using clonotypr: * AnalyzeCDR3Length() –> tabular output * PlotLengths() –> visual output

Length Table

Generate a table merging cell barcodes with frequency data:

barcodefreqs <- GetBarcodeFreqs(clono)
#> GetBarcodeFreqs will be deprecated in clonotypr 1.0.0. Use the updated params in MakeFrequencyDF for same functionality
#> MakeBarcodeDF will be deprecated in clonotypr 1.0.0
lengths <- AnalyzeCDR3Lengths(barcodefreqs, productive=TRUE)
head(lengths)
cdr3s_aa alpha alpha.length beta beta.length
TRA:CVVSQAGTALIF;TRB:CASSFLSPGANVLTF CVVSQAGTALIF 12 CASSFLSPGANVLTF 15
TRA:CAMSLGSNYQLIW;TRB:CASSMGVTDTQYF CAMSLGSNYQLIW 13 CASSMGVTDTQYF 13
TRA:CAASMGDKIIF;TRB:CASSYGQGGLHEQYF CAASMGDKIIF 11 CASSYGQGGLHEQYF 15
TRA:CAVLDSNYQLIW;TRB:CASSYGGDGNVYEQYF CAVLDSNYQLIW 12 CASSYGGDGNVYEQYF 16
TRA:CILRDVETSYDKVIF;TRB:CASSFGGTDTQYF CILRDVETSYDKVIF 15 CASSFGGTDTQYF 13
TRA:CAMRESEDSSYKLIF;TRB:CAISEGLSQPPPETQYF CAMRESEDSSYKLIF 15 CAISEGLSQPPPETQYF 17

Plotting Lengths

length_dist <- PlotLengths(lengths)

length_dist[1] # CDR3alpha lengths
#> [[1]]

length_dist[2] # CDR3beta lengths
#> [[1]]

length_dist[3] # Combined lengths
#> [[1]]

CDR3 AA Composition

To analyze the amino acid composition of a sample, we can break it down by CDR3 length and then focus on each amino acid position to study the diversity. clonotypr offers two strategies for CDR3 composition analysis:
* AnalyzeCDR3aa() –> tabular output
* PlotCDR3aa() –> visual output

CDR3 Position Matrices

AnalyzeCDR3aa builds position matrices, returned as a list of dataframes [instead of matrices]. These provide a quantitative measure of amino acid composition between CDR3 sequences of different lengths. Read more about them here
Three output options are available:
* Position Frequency Matrix (PFM)
* Position Probability Matrix (PPM)
* Position Weight Matrix (PWM)

matrices <- clonotypr::AnalyzeCDR3aa(clono, chain = "alpha", pseudocount = 1, output = "PPM")
matrices[[4]]
aa1 aa2 aa3 aa4 aa5 aa6 aa7 aa8 aa9 aa10 aa11
A 0.0042 3.7542 0.8375 0.0875 0.1708 0.2542 0.5875 0.0875 0.0042 0.0042 0.0042

Plot CDR3 Composition

We can analyze the PWM as seqlogos using PlotCDR3aa. This output can be used to visualize sequence probabilities for sequences of all lengths across the sample

comp <- PlotCDR3aa(lengths)
comp[1] # <- CDR3alpha chains
#> [[1]]

comp[2] # <- CDR3beta chains
#> [[1]]

Plot CDR3 Position Matrices

Although, they’ve been integrated into AnalyzeCDR3aa, clonotypr allows shorthand for computing each type of position matrix using:
* BuildPFM() –> List of Position Frequency Matrices
* BuildPPM() –> List of Position Probability Matrices
* BuildPWM() –> List of Position Weight Matrices

These are the product of earlier development and will be deprecated later on.

The tabular output from these functions and AnalyzeCDR3aa allow for plotting heatmaps of the position matrices. Individual functions are provided for each type of matrix:
* PlotPFM() –> List of PFM Heatmaps
* PlotPPM() –> List of PPM Heatmaps
* PlotPWM() –> List of PWM Heatmaps

matrices <- BuildPPM(data=pbmc_vdj, chain="alpha", pseudocount=1)
plots <- PlotPPM(matrices = matrices)
plots[[6]]
